In a unanimous vote, the Hallsville ISD School Board approved the purchase of 2,500 Google Chromebooks to serve the needs of the students and staff. This is the first phase of the District’s virtual learning plan. This move not only benefits the at home learning education platform, but it also equips students with 21st century technical skills in the classroom.

Going forward more work will be done to improve and upgrade the District’s technology infrastructure as well as expanding the number of devices available to staff and students. This first phase of the virtual learning plan is a huge step in moving the District toward a 1:1 status, equipping all HISD students with a technology device.

“We are very excited for our staff and students, and we thank the board for their continued support,” said Superintendent Jeff Collum.

This morning we had our alternative to walking Kaitlyn Anderson to class on her last day of school. Today would have been her last “real” day of school. When we got in she was greeted so warmly by her kindergarten teacher and her last period teacher. The first and the last. Surprisingly I held it together! It was so sweet of her teachers to take the time out of their day to meet us at the school to make this special moment for her!!! Shout out to Mrs O’Dowd and Mr Mah!!!!!!I can not thank them enough!!! Mr Mah even had her walk in and out of his classroom for the last time😢😢. It may not have been the traditional moment we had been planning for years but it was just as great!!!

Thank you for your patience and prayers for us all as we continue to navigate this situation together as a team.

NOTE: Railroad crossings at FM 450 and at South Cypress Street will be closed from Sunday, January 12 through Tuesday, January 14. These closings will drastically affect transporting our students to and from school on Monday and Tuesday. We are asking everyone to exercise caution and patience as we work through these delays. Bobcat Families: The Hallsville ISD Board of Trustees voted unanimously to call a $55 million bond election for November 5, 2019.

The bond package was developed through an in-depth process of information gathering, research, and community input. The Board of Trustees worked with staff for more than a year to study growth trends, facility assessments and financial data before convening the Bond Steering Committee to seek input from the community. The Bond Steering Committee was a group of more than 35 Hallsville residents and taxpayers who represented a diverse cross-section of the school district. The Board received a recommendation, studied options, and deliberated before voting unanimously to call for a bond election.

For more information about the bond election as well as details about the proposed projects, visit www.HallsvilleISDBond.com.

The dedication of Colton Clark’s Eagle Scout Service Project was held on Sunday in a very moving ceremony. Colton is an amazing young man with a special calling. His service project glorifies God and honors the lives of his fellow Boy Scouts, Will Brannon, Heath Faucheux, and Thomas Larry, who were killed in a tragic accident in August 2017.

The prayer garden and the old rugged cross display will serve First Baptist Hallsville and the community for many years to come.

“Special thanks to everyone who supported my project through prayers and financial donations. This would not have been possible without you. Finally, to my parents and brother, words cannot express how much I appreciate the love and time you have given to help me succeed,” Colton said.

IT'S NATIONAL PRINCIPAL APPRECIATION MONTH

Danieli Parker is the principal at Hallsville North Elementary. A native of Roswell, New Mexico, she moved to Texas after graduating from New Mexico State University with a degree in Elementary Education. Her teaching career began at North East Independent School District in San Antonio, Texas.

Mrs. Parker moved to Longview in December 2007 after her husband’s job transferred him here. She taught at Longview ISD for the remainder of that school year and was then hired in Hallsville to teach second grade. In 2009, she was hired as the assistant principal of the Intermediate campus, and worked there for two years. She left for a couple of years, but returned to serve as principal at North Elementary.

Thank you, Mrs. Parker, for inspiring our students to dream more, learn more, do more and become more. You are appreciated!!

Test Drive a Ford and Earn $20 for Your School

What: The @HallsvilleEdFdn is partnering with Pegues Hurst Ford Motor Company to bring Ford's Drive 4UR School Test Drive event back to Hallsville. Take a spin in a new Ford vehicle. When: Thursday, August 16, 4-8PM...before, during, and after the Community Wide Pep Rally

Where: Hallsville High School Coliseum Parking Lot,
616 Cal Young Road, Hallsville
